sense.name: the rotating motion of an object
sense.examples: The jet began its roll down the runway. (wheels are rotating) The dog enjoyed a long roll in the grass. We practiced forward rolls in gymnastics today. Mary gave the bowling ball a roll that sent it down the center of the lane. He sensed Sally's annoyance by the roll of her eyes. (metaphoric extension)

sense.name: a roster of names
sense.commentary: ROLL[+artifact][+document][+roster][+of_names] Note: contrast this to Sense 14, which refers to the people on the roster
sense.examples: The teacher read of each student's name from the roll. One diver got scolded for not signing the roll on the dive boat.

sense.name: long, heavy ocean waves
sense.examples: The ocean's roll gradually increased as they headed out to sea. Head the boat diagonally into the roll so she doesn't wallow between the waves. We enjoyed the roll of the hills in the bucolic rural landscape. (metaphoric extension to static land form)

sense.name: a contiguous batch of photographic film
sense.commentary: ROLL[+artifact][+film][+photographic][+batch][+contiguous] Note: narrow, specialized usage of Sense 5 referring just to film
sense.examples: Sally dropped a fresh roll of film into her camera. John took five rolls of film to be developed at the camera shop.

sense.name: any cylindrical or coiled form
sense.examples: The two men carried a large roll of white carpet into the building. The shelf was stacked with rolls of toilet paper. The cashier broke open a roll of quarters and put them in the register. The waitress put a plate of sushi rolls in front of us. John cracked open a roll of mints and passed them around. The young leaves of the plant were still in tight rolls, not yet unfurled.

sense.name: a wad of currency bills
sense.commentary: ROLL[+collection][+artifact][+bills][+currency][+wad] Note: specialized, narrow usage related to Sense 5, but always refers to a wad of paper money
sense.examples: Bob pulled out a roll of hundreds and pulled off two to pay the tab. He kept twenty-dollar bills in one roll, and fifties in another.

sense.name: small rounded bread
sense.examples: We started the meal with a basket of hot rolls. Mary ate a cinnamon roll for breakfast. This is a great recipe for yeast rolls.

sense.name: a deep, prolonged sound
sense.examples: We heard the distant roll of thunder as the sky darkened. The deep roll coming from the mountain was the sound of an avalanche.

sense.name: rapid percussive sound of a drum
sense.examples: The drummer gave a roll just before the master of ceremonies announced the winner. Johnny practiced his rolls and brushes with his drum set.

sense.name: a scrolled up document
sense.examples: The ancient library had thousands of rolls of parchment. The blueprints of the building lay in rolls on the architect's drawing board.

sense.name: a throw of the dice
sense.examples: John threw double sixes two rolls in a row. The gambler blew on the dice for luck before he made his roll. It's Mary's roll next. (her turn to throw the dice in a game)

sense.name: a manner of moving with a swaying motion
sense.examples: Sailors in port often walk with a roll down the street. This car can turn corners briskly with a minimum of roll. They were mesmerized by the roll of the belly dancer's hips.

sense.name: aerobatic maneuver with longitudinal rotation
sense.examples: The stunt pilot performed amazing barrel rolls at the air show. The two aerobatic planes performed a series of rolls and then a loop.

sense.name: the people who are registered attendees
sense.examples: They are conducting a review of the school district to assess the impact of falling rolls. The attendance roll at this conference is ten percent higher than last year.

sense.name: IDIOMS
sense.commentary: ON_A_ROLL (having extended period of success) A_ROLL_IN_THE_HAY/SACK (have sex with someone)
sense.examples: John's been on a roll with his electronic inventions lately. All he wanted from Sally was a quick roll in the hay.
